Bromine atoms contribute to higher molecular weight and van der Waals interactions; each bromine might lead to an increase of about +7°C, rather than +15°C, which would more accurately reflect its impact on the melting point given the actual value we have. With two bromines, the combined effect would be +14°C. Summing the effects, the predicted increase is +94°C when adding the influence of the amino group and the bromine atoms to the base melting point of pyridine.
